metadata.subject: Teaching Minds: How Cognitive Science Can Save Our Schools

organizations: U.S. House Committee on Oversight and Accountability

relationships.description: Schank critically analyzes traditional education systems and proposes cognitive process-based reforms
Schank argues universities inadvertently ruin schools by imposing subject-based curriculum requirements
Schank redefines the teacher-student relationship as mentoring rather than lecturing

analysis.purpose: To propose a radical overhaul of education based on cognitive science principles
analysis.significance: Challenges fundamental assumptions about teaching and learning that have dominated education for over a century

notable_quotes: 'Teaching isn't what outsiders to the profession think it is. Learning isn't what outsiders to the profession think it is.'

'The problem with schools lies in our conception of the role of school. We see school as a place to study academics, to become a scholar, when in fact very few students actually want to become scholars or study academics.'
'If we must have subjects in school, why wouldn't dating be rated as way more important than mathematics?'
red_flags: Vested interests in maintaining current testing industry

blackmail_indicators.description: Document is an educational philosophy book with no indications of blackmail or coercion

illegal_activity.description: Academic work about education reform with no illegal activity

details: References to media coverage of education issues
Mentions of interviews with political figures
Discussion of how media portrays educational testing

public_knowledge.context: Book published by academic press discussing publicly debated education reform issues

analysis.summary: Roger Schank's book critiques traditional subject-based education and proposes a cognitive process-based approach focusing on 12 fundamental learning processes. He argues that current educational systems fail because they emphasize memorization over practical thinking skills and are overly influenced by university requirements that don't serve most students' needs.
